metadata./Title: Genotypic and phenotypic analysis of an oculocutaneous albinism patient: a case report and review of the literature

sections.Background:
Background Oculocutaneous albinism is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by congenital melanin deficiency, resulting in hypopigmentation of the eyes, hair, and skin. This study included a Chinese family with an oculocutaneous albinism pedigree, in which the proband presented with oculocutaneous albinismcombined 
with secondary angle closure, which has been rarely reported in previous literature. This article primarily focused 
on the clinical and genetic examination

sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation The proband in this case study is a 53-year-old Chinese male who showed depigmentation 
of the skin, hair, iris, and fundus, accompanied by photophobia, decreased vision, high intraocular pressure, nystagmus, macular fovea hypoplasia, and cataracts. Owing to the opacity and expansion of the lens, the volume ratio 
of lens to eyeball was increased, causing crowded anterior segment, bombed iris, and narrowed chamber angle and, 
ultimately, leading to secondary angle closure. Whole-exome sequencing suggested that the two patients in the pedigree harbored the compound heterozygous variants c.230G > A (p. Arg77Gln) and c.832G > A (p. Arg278*) in the TYR   
gene, while the healthy member carried the TYR   c.230G > A (p. Arg77Gln) variant, which was consistent with the auto somal recessive inheritance pattern and further confirmed the diagnosis was oculocutaneous albinism. On the basis 
of the above results, the patient was diagnosed with oculocutaneous albinism, senile mature cataract, and secondary 
angle closure in the right eye and ocular hypertension in the left eye, as well as bilateral nystagmus. Then, the patient 
was prescribed carteolol eye drops to control intraocular pressure and underwent phacoemulsification and intraocular lens implantation surgery for the right eye. Postoperatively, the patient’s intraocular pressure was effectively 
controlled, and visual acuity improved.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion We report a patient with oculocutaneous albinism combined with cataract and secondary angle closure, 
and whole-exome sequencing suggested that he harbored TYR   gene variants. Comprehensive examinations were 
important for identifying the causes of angle closure and making proper treatment strategies. Genetic testing enabled 
precise diagnosis and genetic counseling.

reports on OCA combined with secondary angle closure, 
and no case reports about the genetic testing for these 
patients. This study includes a Chinese family with OCA 
, in which the subject of this case study showed OCA and 
secondary angle closure. We aim to analyze the genotype 
and phenotype of the patient and review the recent rel evant literature to enhance our understanding of the dis ease. In addition, we hope to provide some insights and 
experiences to assist other ophthalmologists in managing 
similar patients.
Case presentation
Clinical findings
A 53-year-old Chinese male patient presented to oph thalmic clinic with decreased visual acuity in both eyes 
for 6 months and worsened during 3 months. Owing to 
insufficient understanding of the disease, the patient had 
not received regular treatment before. He had a family 
history of albinism for over 50  years and was the sixth 
child of nonconsanguineous parents. Among his five sib lings, one sister also had albinism, while the other four 
siblings did not. Their parents had passed away, and the 
patient complained that they had no clinical manifesta tions of albinism (the family tree is presented in Fig. 1).
Through general physical examinations, we found that 
the proband had normal intelligence and developmen tal history. He had the typical manifestation of albinism, 
which was white skin and hair over the whole body. His 
neck was symmetrical in appearance and normal in 
movement, the thyroid gland was not palpable, and there 
were no obvious positive signs in the heart, lungs, abdo men, surrounding blood vessels, musculoskeletal system, 
reproductive system, and nervous system.
The ophthalmologic examinations showed his visual 
acuity was light perception (LP) in the right eye and 0.08 
in the left eye. Following a week of the administration of carteolol drops at the initial visit in our hospital, the 
intraocular pressure (IOP) was 22.3  mmHg in the right 
and 24.4  mmHg in the left with an air puff tonometer. 
Slit lamp examination showed the white palpebral skin 
and eyelashes with nystagmus in both eyes. The ocular 
alignment was orthotropic and the eye movement was 
normal. There was no obvious congestion or edema in 
the conjunctiva of both eyes. The cornea of the right eye 
was transparent, with a central anterior chamber depth 
of about 3 corneal thickness (CT) and a peripheral ante rior chamber depth of about one-fourth of the CT. The 
pupil was round, with a diameter of about 3  mm and 
sensitive to light reflection. The iris was widely depig mented, and the lens appeared opaque and swollen, lead ing to poor visibility of the fundus. The cornea of the 
left eye was transparent with a normal anterior chamber 
depth and slightly cloudy lens. The fundus in the left eye 
showed widespread depigmentation of the retina and 
choroid, and the choroidal blood vessels could be seen 
(Fig.  2). Optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed 
the refractive interstitial opacity in the right eye and no 
signal in the macular area and macular fovea hypoplasia 
in the left eye (Fig.  3). Ultrasonic biological microscope 
(UBM) showed the chamber angle was narrow, and the 
anterior chamber was shallow in the right eye, with the 
central anterior chamber depth of 1.81  mm and central 
corneal thickness of 520 μm, while the chamber angle of 
the left eye was open in all quadrants, and the depth of 
central anterior chamber was 2.71  mm and central cor neal thickness of 525  μm (Fig.  4). The axial length was 
23.85 mm in the right eye and 26.51 mm in the left eye, 
and the thickness of the lens was 5.62 mm in the right eye 
and 3.88  mm in the left eye measured by B-scan ultra sonography. Spotted and clustered echoes can be seen in 
the vitreouses of both eyes, with high activity. No obvious 
abnormalities observed in the retina and orbit (Fig.  5). 
Gonioscopy was not performed.
Genetic findings
To further investigate the genetic pathogenesis of the 
family, the whole blood samples were collected from 
three subjects (patients II:2, II:6, and healthy member 
III:2), after obtaining written informed consent from all 
subjects. The genomic DNA for whole-exome sequencing 
(WES) was extracted, and then, bioinformatics analysis 
was performed on the sequencing results. On the basis of 
the ACMG genetic variation classification standards and 
guidelines, suspicious pathogenic variants were screened 
and validated by Sanger sequencing.
The study found the two patients, II:2 and II:6, har bored compound heterozygous variants c.230G > A (p. 
Arg77Gln) and c. 832G > A (p. Arg278*) in the TYR  gene. 
Both of these variants were a heterozygous variant. The

Diagnosis, treatment, and follow‑up results
On the basis of the above genotypic and phenotypic 
results, the proband was diagnosed with OCA, senile 
mature cataract, secondary angle closure in the right eye, 
and ocular hypertension in the left eye, as well as bilateral 
nystagmus. At the initial visit, the patient was prescribed carteolol eye drops twice daily to control IOP . Medication 
was adjusted based on follow-up IOP conditions. Simul taneously, relevant preoperative examinations were con ducted to exclude any surgical contraindications. Under 
local anesthesia, the patient underwent phacoemulsifi cation and intraocular lens implantation surgery for the 
right eye.
The patient underwent regular follow-up after surgery 
and demonstrated good adherence to the treatment plan. 
On the first postoperative day, the visual acuity improved 
to 0.08 with an IOP of 18.3 mmHg in the right eye, while 
the visual acuity was 0.08 with an IOP of 24.7 mmHg in

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
OCA is an autosomal recessive inherited disorder char acterized by reduced or complete absence of melanin 
synthesis in the skin, hair, and eyes. The prevalence is 
around 1 in 20,000 to 1 in 10,000 individuals [1–4]. The 
main clinical features are characterized by infantile-onset 
nystagmus, photophobia, visual impairment, hypopig mentation of the iris and fundus, dysplastic macular 
fovea, refractive errors, and sometimes a degree of color 
vision impairment, as well as depigmentation of the skin 
and hair [1]. There are limited reports on the coexist ence of OCA and ocular hypertension or angle closure, 
most of these articles focused on the treatment of these 
patients. For example, R.A. Catalano described an infant 
with oculocutaneous albinism and congenital glaucoma 
[5]. A.D. Dotson reported a case of unsuccessful transs cleral cyclophotocoagulation in an oculocutaneous albi nism patient [6]. D. Pásztor reported the management 
of a patient with oculocutaneous albinism, keratoconus, 
total cataract, and glaucoma. These articles all did not 
report the genetic results of these patients [7]. In this 
study, we collected a Chinese OCA pedigree with two 
affected members, focused on the clinical and genetic 
examination results of the patient, and provided recom mendations for ophthalmologists to treat patients with 
OCA in their  clinical  practice. The study findings indi cate that the proband showed secondary angle closure, 
and genetic testing revealed he harbored compound het erozygous variants in the TYR  gene.
The detailed ophthalmic and systemic examinations 
showed the proband had the depigmentation of the skin, 
hair, iris, and fundus, accompanied with photophobia, 
decreased visual acuity, elevated IOP , nystagmus, dysplas tic macular fovea, and cataract; these clinical manifesta tions were similar to previously reported patients with OCA[8]. However, the proband presented with second ary angle closure due to the opacity and swelling of lens, 
and there were few related reports about this. OCA can 
be associated with two types of angle-closure glaucoma: 
primary angle-closure glaucoma and secondary angleclosure glaucoma [5, 7]. Primary angle-closure glaucoma 
primarily occurs in patients with OCA with anterior seg ment dysgenesis (ASD) [9], which involves congenital 
maldevelopment in various anterior segment structures 
such as the cornea, iris, lens, and anterior chamber angle, 
and owing to the dysplasia of the aqueous outflow struc tures originating from neural crest cells, approximately 
50% of these patients develop glaucoma. Astigmatism 
was the most common visually significant refractive error 
in albinism [10], and the proportion of hyperopia and 
myopia were similar [11]. Secondary angle-closure glau coma often occurs in patients with OCA with hyperopia 
and astigmatism [10, 12]. Patients with hyperopia com monly present with a shorter axial length, and, as they 
age, the thickness of the lens increases. This combination 
can result in a shallower anterior chamber and a nar rower angle, ultimately leading to the development of 
angle-closure glaucoma. In the study, the patient had an 
axial length of 23.85 mm in the right eye and 26.51 mm 
in the left eye. The thickness of the lens was measured 
as 5.62 mm in the right eye and 3.88 mm in the left eye. 
These findings indicate that the pathogenic mechanism 
of angle closure in the right eye of this patient was pri marily due to lens thickening, resulting in an increased 
lens-to-eye volume ratio. This, in turn, led to crowding of 
the anterior segment, resulting in angle narrowing and, 
subsequently, developing into secondary angle closure. 
Therefore, we performed phacoemulsification combined 
with intraocular lens implantation. After the surgery, the 
patient’s anterior chamber deepened, the angle opened 
up, and IOP was well controlled. This case highlights 
the importance for ophthalmologists to carefully exam ine various structures in the anterior segment, including 
the anterior chamber and angle, when evaluating patients 
with OCA. Detailed ophthalmic examination, especially 
examination of the anterior segment, can identify the 
cause of angle closure and contribute to make appropri ate and proper treatment measures. For patients above 
the age of 40 years, it is crucial to be vigilant about the 
possibility of secondary angle closure caused by lens 
opacity and thickening. In terms of treatment, it is neces sary to identify the underlying cause of angle closure to 
provide appropriate and effective management.
OCA is a genetically heterogeneous disorder with 
autosomal recessive inheritance. It presents with a 
variety of clinical manifestations and can be classified 
into syndromic and nonsyndromic types based on the 
involvement of other organ systems. Syndromic OCA 
Page 6 of 7 Ma and Wang  Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:624 
is often associated with systemic abnormalities includ ing immunodeficiency, pulmonary fibrosis, hemato logical abnormalities, neurological impairments, and 
so on. Two examples of syndromic OCA are Herman sky–Pudlak syndrome (HPS) and Chediak–Higashi 
syndrome (CHS) [4 ]. HPS encompasses 11 subtypes, 
namely HPS1-11, which are caused by variants in the 
HPS1, AP3B1, HPS3, HPS4, HPS5, HPS6, DTNBP1, 
BLOC1S3, BLOC1S6, AP3D1, and BLOC1S5 genes 
[13–17], and the pathogenic gene for CHS is LYST  
[18, 19]. Patients with HPS and CHS can exhibit simi lar clinical manifestations, therefore, genetic testing 
can contribute to an accurate diagnosis. Nonsyndro mic OCA can be further classified into seven types, 
which are caused by variants in the TYR , OCA2, 
TYRP1, SLC45A2, SLC24A5, LRMDA, and DCT genes, 
respectively [20– 24]. Among these subtypes, OCA1 
is the most common subtype and can be divided into 
OCA1A and OCA1B. Different subtypes have some 
overlap or similar phenotypes. The overlap of phe notypes makes it difficult to accurately classify and 
diagnose solely on the basis of clinical manifestations 
[1, 25]. For instance, patients with OCA1A showed 
a complete absence of pigment in the hair, eyes, and 
skin. The phenotypes of OCA1B and OCA2 are typi cally somewhat less severe than OCA1A, and the two 
subtypes show considerable clinical overlap [26]. The 
above findings emphasize the importance of molecu lar diagnosis in accurate diagnosis and classification. 
Furthermore, identifying pathogenic genes can pro vide better genetic counseling for patients. Carrier 
detection and prenatal diagnosis are possible when the 
disease-causing mutations have been identified in the 
family.
Through WES and bioinformatics analysis, we found 
that the two patients harbored compound heterozy gous variants c.230G > A (p. Arg77Gln) and c. 832G > A 
(p. Arg278*) in the TYR  gene. One healthy member 
carried the heterozygous variant c.230G > A (p. Arg 77Gln) in TYR  gene. These results were consistent 
with the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern and 
further confirmed the diagnosis of the patients was 
OCA1. These findings showed genetic testing can be 
used for precise diagnosis of genetically heterogene ous disorder with overlapping clinical manifestations, 
which can enable clinicians to provide precise genetic 
counseling, prognostic information, and personalized 
treatment strategies for patients. A limitation of this 
study is that owing to the deceased parents and geo graphical distance, it was not possible to obtain phe notypic and genotypic information of the proband’s 
parents and siblings.Conclusion
We report a patient with OCA combined with cataract and 
secondary angle-closure, and WES suggested that he har bored TYR  gene variants. Comprehensive examinations 
were important for identifying the causes of angle-closure 
and making proper treatment strategies. Genetic testing 
enabled precise diagnosis and genetic counseling. Addi tionally, genetic screening contributes to the accurate diag nosis, follow-up, and genetic counseling.

Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
Ethical approval was not applicable. This study had no novel intervention 
and all treatments were standard treatments of an oculocutaneous albinism 
combined with angle closure. All patients gave written, informed consent to 
publish these cases and any accompanying images.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of 
this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent 
is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
